content: Eligibility for health benefits under CHIP is available to different groups through various federal authorities and mechanisms, including children, pregnant women, parents, and childless adults. Title XXI defines a targeted low-income child as someone under 19 without health insurance and not eligible for Medicaid before March 31, 1997. States can set the income level for these children up to 200% of the federal poverty level. States have the authority to expand eligibility for all children under 19, with CMS approval required for certain expansions. Under current statutory and regulatory authority, states can expand eligibility for children under 19 to any level they choose. CHIPRA reduces federal payments for higher-income CHIP children, using the regular Medicaid FMAP for those with family incomes over 300% of poverty. States can assist qualifying children through their Medicaid programs or other means. States can provide assistance to qualifying children through their Medicaid programs or separate CHIP programs. Medicaid rules apply when covering low-income children under Medicaid, while Title XXI rules apply for separate CHIP programs. Federal CHIP funds cover the program costs, and states with approved CHIP plans receive federal allotments based on a distribution formula. Title XXI does not establish individual entitlement to benefits. Title XXI does not establish individual entitlement to benefits for low-income children covered under separate CHIP programs. States can cover these children by expanding Medicaid programs through new eligibility groups or liberalizing financial rules. Many states with Medicaid-expansion CHIP programs chose this approach. States have the option to cover targeted low-income children under existing Medicaid eligibility pathways or by establishing a separate CHIP program. This strategy reduces administrative burden and allows states to define eligibility based on factors such as geography, age, income, and resources. States can determine eligibility for separate CHIP programs based on factors like geography, age, income, resources, residency, disability status, access to other health insurance, and duration of CHIP eligibility. Before CHIPRA, states could cover adult pregnant women through waivers or by providing prenatal care and delivery services to unborn children through a CHIP state plan amendment. States can extend coverage to pregnant women through Section 1115 waivers or CHIP state plan amendments. As of October 2007, 17 states offered pregnancy-related services to adults using CHIP funds, with some states extending coverage to unborn children as well. In FY2008, 364,161 unborn children were enrolled in CHIP, with nearly half in California. CHIPRA added a new state option to cover pregnant women under CHIP through a state plan amendment, with certain conditions to be met by states. Pregnant women must meet income requirements and have no pre-existing conditions to be eligible for CHIP coverage. Coverage includes prenatal, delivery, and postpartum care, with infants born to these women also eligible for Medicaid or CHIP. States can provide temporary coverage for up to two months through presumptive eligibility. Benefits for pregnant women under CHIP include all services available to CHIP children, prenatal, delivery, and postpartum care. Infants born to these women are eligible for Medicaid or CHIP up to age one, with eligibility subject to redetermination. States may also offer postpartum services and coverage for legal immigrants after a five-year bar. The law requires sponsor's income and resources to be considered for legal immigrants, not refugees or asylees, in determining eligibility for federally means-tested programs. CHIPRA allowed states to waive the five-year bar for Medicaid or CHIP coverage for pregnant women and eligible children. The CHIP state plan option is available to states that elect this provision. The CHIPRA law allows states to waive the five-year bar for Medicaid or CHIP coverage for pregnant women and eligible children who are lawfully residing in the United States. States that elect this provision can provide assistance for pregnant women under the CHIP state plan option. The provision ensures that the cost of care will not be counted against an individual's sponsor, and individuals must provide further documentation if their initial legal residence documentation expires during redetermination processes. Under current law, Section 1115 of the Social Security Act grants the Secretary of Health and Human Services broad authority to modify aspects of CHIP programs, including expanding eligibility to populations not typically eligible. States can use waivers to cover adults with CHIP funds, subject to renewal every three years. Individuals eligible under this provision must provide further documentation if their initial legal residence documentation expires during redetermination processes. Certain states have covered adults with CHIP funds through waivers, initially effective for five years and subject to renewal every three years. Prior to 2007, waiver renewals were approved even for states facing federal CHIP shortfalls. However, since 2007, some waiver renewals have not been approved or states have begun transitioning adult populations out of CHIP coverage. As of January 7, 2009, 4 states have CMS authority to use CHIP funds to extend coverage to childless adult populations, and 7 states have authority to cover parent populations. CHIPRA made changes to mental health and substance abuse coverage, ensuring that financial requirements and treatment limitations for these benefits are no more restrictive than those for medical and surgical benefits. State CHIP plans must adhere to mental health parity requirements, ensuring that financial requirements and treatment limitations for mental health and substance abuse disorder benefits are no more restrictive than those for medical and surgical benefits. Dental services are now a required benefit under separate CHIP programs, including services to prevent disease, promote oral health, restore oral structures, and treat emergency conditions. The new law requires dental services for children under CHIP programs, including preventive care, oral health promotion, and treatment for emergencies. A study by GAO will assess children's access to dental care under Medicaid and CHIP, with recommendations for addressing barriers and using mid-level providers. Cost-sharing refers to out-of-pocket payments made by beneficiaries of a health insurance plan, including monthly premiums, deductibles, copayments, and coinsurance. States can impose cost-sharing for some beneficiaries and services under CHIP, following nominal cost-sharing rules for targeted low-income children under Medicaid. DRA provided states with new options for premiums and cost-sharing for low-income children under CHIP Medicaid-expansion programs based on family income levels. Premiums are not allowed for families under 100% FPL, while service-related cost-sharing is limited. Families with income between 100%-150% FPL may have service-related cost-sharing up to 10%, and those above 150% FPL may have premiums and cost-sharing up to 20%. The DRA allows for cost-sharing up to 10% for children in families with income between 100%-150% FPL, and up to 20% for those above 150% FPL. Total cost-sharing cannot exceed 5% of family income. CHIPRA 2009 aimed to improve data collection and reporting for CHIP and Medicaid, including developing child health quality measures and standardized reporting formats. The CHIPRA 2009 law directed the Secretary of HHS to develop child health quality measures and reporting formats for CHIP and Medicaid. It also added reporting requirements to states' annual CHIP reports, including data on eligibility criteria and access to care. A study on children's access to care under Medicaid and CHIP was mandated, and a new federal commission called MACPAC was established to review policies affecting children's benefits. The CHIPRA 2009 law mandated the establishment of a new federal commission, MACPAC, to review policies affecting children's benefits under Medicaid and CHIP. The commission will provide regular reports to Congress with recommendations for improving access and quality of care for children. Additionally, the law required the Secretary of HHS to conduct a federal evaluation of 10 states with approved CHIP plans to assess effectiveness of outreach and enrollment. The federal evaluation of CHIP coverage will assess outreach strategies, cost-sharing effects, disenrollment factors, and retention of children.
